Chapter 2 Hypothesis Testing 2.1 Rock-Paper-Scissors # This example illustrate how to find the binomial distribution of the Rock-Paper-Scissors example numberTrial <- 12 parameter <- 1/3 probability <- function(n, x) { factorial(n) / factorial(n-x) / factorial(x)*(parameter)^x*(1-parameter)^(n-x) } # create a dataframe for saving the probability of different number of scissors thrown out of 12 times under the null hypothesis distvector <- vector('numeric',length = 13) for (i in 0:12){ distvector[i+1] <- probability(12,i) } dis <- as.data.frame(cbind(seq(0,12),distvector)) dis ## V1 distvector ## 1 0 7.707347e-03 ## 2 1 4.624408e-02 ## 3 2 1.271712e-01 ## 4 3 2.119520e-01 ## 5 4 2.384460e-01 ## 6 5 1.907568e-01 ## 7 6 1.112748e-01 ## 8 7 4.768921e-02 ## 9 8 1.490288e-02 ## 10 9 3.311751e-03 ## 11 10 4.967626e-04 ## 12 11 4.516023e-05 ## 13 12 1.881676e-06 # Plot the distribution of throwing scissors barplot(dis$distvector,ylim=c(0,0.3),names.arg = dis$V1)
